title:
A dynamical mechanism rooted in the Lorenz system for giant negative and
  positive mobility of a memory-driven active particle
authors: Rahil N. Valani, Bruno S. Dandogbessi
abstract:
On applying a small bias force, non-equilibrium systems may respond in
paradoxical ways such as with giant negative mobility (GNM) -- a large net
drift opposite to the applied bias, or giant positive mobility (GPM) -- an
anomalously large drift in the same direction as the applied bias. We consider
an idealized model of a memory-driven active particle inspired from experiments
with walking/superwalking droplets that takes the form of the celebrated Lorenz
system. By adding a small bias force to this Lorenz model, we uncover a
mechanism for simultaneous emergence of GNM and GPM in the parameter space.
Within the chaotic sea of the parameter space, a symmetric pair of coexisting
asymmetric limit cycles separate and migrate under applied bias force,
resulting in anomalous transport behaviors that are sensitive to the particle's
memory. This provides a general dynamical mechanism for the emergence of
anomalous transport behaviors for self-driven particles described by
low-dimensional autonomous chaotic systems.
